column1: The '''Black Speech''' was created by [[Sauron]] during the [[Dark Years]] to be the sole language of all the servants of Mordor
column2: replacing the many different varieties of [[Orkish]] and other languages used by his servants. When Sauron was overthrown at the end of the [[Second Age]] the ancient "pure" form was forgotten by all but the [[Nazgûl]].  When Sauron returned it was once again made the official language of [[Barad-dûr]].  However
column3: a more "debased" form was used by the soldiery of [[Barad-dûr]] at the end of the [[Third Age]].<ref name="Trans">{{App|Translation}}</ref> The only example given of "pure" Black Speech is the inscription upon [[the One Ring]]<ref>{{FR|II2}}</ref>:

column1: One Ring to rule them all
One Ring to bring them all and in the darkness bind them.
These are the first two lines from the end of a [[Ring Verse|verse]] about the [[Rings of Power]].
Many Orkish dialects had adopted words from it.<ref name="Trans"/> The Black Speech was at least in part based on [[Valarin]].

column2: [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] created this language with the intention of making it harsh and ugly.{{fact}} The Black Speech is one of the more incomplete languages in Tolkien's novels
column3: because the forces of good refuse to utter it.

column1: Tolkien linguist [[Helge Fauskanger]] has noted a theory proposed by Russian historian Alexander Nemirovski
column3: according to the shape of words
